merged.Adrenal Function Tests (ACTH, Cortisol): Suppressed ACTH and cortisol levels, indicating adrenal insufficiency with prolonged use.
merged.Albumin: Decreased albumin levels due to plasma removal
merged.Amylase and Lipase: Elevated levels indicating possible pancreatitis (e.g., tetracyclines or sulfonamides).
merged.Antinuclear Antibodies (ANA): Positive results linked to drug-induced lupus-like syndrome, particularly with minocycline or other antibiotics.
merged.Bilirubin: Elevated levels due to hemolysis during the procedure
merged.Blood Culture: Potential false-positive results due to transient bacteremia during central line placement or infusion.
merged.Blood Glucose: Hyperglycemia, potentially leading to new-onset diabetes after transplantation (NODAT).
merged.Blood Pressure: Hypertension, frequently reported in patients on cyclosporine.
merged.Bone Density (DEXA Scan): Decreased bone mineral density, indicating osteoporosis or osteopenia with prolonged corticosteroid use.
merged.Bone Marrow Biopsy: May show hypocellularity in cases of significant cytopenias.
merged.Bone Turnover Markers (Osteocalcin, CTX): Reduced levels, reflecting suppressed bone formation and increased resorption.
merged.C-Reactive Protein (CRP): Reduced levels due to immunosuppressive effects.
merged.C-Reactive Protein (CRP) / Erythrocyte S: Decreased inflammatory markers due to suppression of infection; may also be unaffected depending on context.
merged.CMV IgG/IgM Antibodies: Decreased response to infection due to impaired immune surveillance.
merged.CMV PCR (Cytomegalovirus Polymerase Chai: Elevated viral load due to increased susceptibility to viral infections from immunosuppression.
merged.Calcium (Ionized Calcium): Decreased ionized calcium due to citrate chelation
merged.Coagulation Profile (PT, aPTT): Prolonged PT and aPTT due to removal of coagulation factors
merged.Coagulation Tests (aPTT, D-dimer): Abnormal clotting parameters, occasionally seen with antibiotics affecting coagulation pathways.
merged.Complement Levels (C3, C4): Decreased complement levels due to immune activation and consumption.
merged.Complete Blood Count (CBC): Leukopenia (low white blood cell count), anemia (low red blood cell count), and thrombocytopenia (low platelet count).
merged.Creatine Kinase (CK): Reduced levels due to muscle wasting or myopathy.
merged.Creatinine: Potential slight increases due to hemoconcentration
merged.Cytokine Levels (e.g., IL-6, TNF-\u03b1): Elevated levels due to cytokine release syndrome during or after infusion.
merged.D-Dimer: Elevated levels in cases of thromboembolic events, although rare.
merged.D-dimer: Elevated levels, potentially indicating activation of the coagulation cascade or thrombotic events.
merged.Direct Antiglobulin Test (DAT/Coombs Tes: Positive in cases of drug-induced hemolytic anemia.
merged.EBV PCR (Epstein-Barr Virus Polymerase C: Elevated viral load, potentially increasing the risk of post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD).
merged.Electrolytes (Potassium, Sodium, Calcium: Hypokalemia (low potassium), hypernatremia (high sodium), and hypocalcemia (low calcium).
merged.Electrolytes (Potassium, Sodium, Magnesi: Imbalances such as hypokalemia or hypomagnesemia, especially with amphotericin B or diuretics used concurrently.
merged.Electrolytes (Sodium, Potassium, Calcium: Imbalances, such as hypocalcemia, due to citrate anticoagulant binding calcium
merged.Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR): Reduced levels due to suppression of inflammatory responses.
merged.Fibrinogen: Low fibrinogen levels due to depletion during plasmapheresis
merged.Haptoglobin: Decreased levels due to hemolysis during plasmapheresis
merged.Immunoglobulins (IgG, IgA, IgM): Lowered immunoglobulin levels due to their removal during the process
merged.LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): Elevated levels due to red blood cell damage during the procedure
merged.Lactic Acid: Elevated levels due to mitochondrial toxicity or impaired oxygen utilization.
merged.Liver Function Tests (ALT, AST, ALP, Bil: Elevated liver enzymes or bilirubin, indicating hepatotoxicity.
merged.Liver Function Tests (ALT, AST, Bilirubi: Elevated levels indicating hepatotoxicity or liver dysfunction.
merged.Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV): Elevated MCV, often seen with chronic azathioprine use.
merged.Parathyroid Hormone (PTH): Elevated levels, particularly in patients with chronic kidney disease.
merged.Peripheral Blood Smear: Cytopenias (reduced blood cells) and changes in cell morphology due to bone marrow suppression.
merged.Potassium: Hypokalemia due to shifts during the procedure
merged.Prothrombin Time (PT) / INR: Prolonged clotting times due to coagulopathy or disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
merged.Pulmonary Function Tests (PFTs): Abnormal results if tacrolimus-induced pulmonary toxicity occurs.
merged.Renal Function Tests (Creatinine, BUN): Elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels, indicating nephrotoxicity.
merged.Serum Albumin: Decreased levels in chronic use due to catabolic effects.
merged.Serum Amylase and Lipase: Elevated levels indicating potential drug-induced pancreatitis.
merged.Serum Calcium and Phosphate: Abnormal levels due to bone metabolism disturbances.
merged.Serum Electrolytes (Potassium, Calcium,: Abnormal levels, including hyperkalemia or hypocalcemia, related to hemolysis or infusion reactions.
merged.Serum Electrolytes (Potassium, Magnesium: Abnormal levels depending on associated renal dysfunction or electrolyte disturbances.
Hyperkalemia (high potassium), hypomagnesemia (low magnesium), and hypernatremia (high sodium).
merged.Serum Ferritin: Elevated levels due to systemic inflammation or macrophage activation syndrome.
merged.Serum Glucose: Hyperglycemia due to metabolic side effects, particularly in patients at risk for diabetes.
merged.Serum Immunoglobulins (IgG, IgA, IgM): Reduced levels due to immunosuppressive effects.
merged.Serum LDH: Elevated levels in cases of hemolysis or tissue damage.
merged.Serum Magnesium: Hypomagnesemia (low magnesium levels), often seen in transplant recipients.
merged.Serum Potassium: Hyperkalemia (elevated potassium levels), particularly in patients with kidney impairment.
merged.Serum Uric Acid: Elevated levels, potentially leading to gout.
merged.T-Cell Subsets (CD3, CD4, CD8): Altered counts due to the selective immunosuppressive action on T cells.
merged.Thioguanine Nucleotide (TGN) Levels: Elevated levels can indicate toxicity due to metabolism of azathioprine.
merged.Thiopurine Methyltransferase (TPMT) Acti: Low or absent TPMT activity increases the risk of severe myelosuppression.
merged.Total Protein: Reduced total protein levels due to plasma removal
merged.Trough Cyclosporine Levels: Abnormal levels (either too high or too low), impacting efficacy or toxicity.
merged.Trough Drug Levels: Abnormal therapeutic drug levels if monitored in specific cases for toxicity or efficacy.
merged.Trough Sirolimus Levels: Abnormal therapeutic drug levels (too high or too low), affecting efficacy or toxicity.
merged.Trough Tacrolimus Levels: Abnormal therapeutic drug levels (too high or too low), impacting efficacy or toxicity.
merged.Uric Acid: Elevated levels due to increased cell turnover or reduced renal excretion.
merged.Urinalysis: Proteinuria, hematuria, or casts indicating kidney involvement.
merged.Urine Calcium Excretion: Increased levels, associated with risk of nephrolithiasis or osteoporosis.
merged.Urine Culture: False negatives or altered results due to pre-sample antibiotic administration.
merged.Vitamin D and Calcium: Low levels associated with impaired bone metabolism and increased fracture risk.
merged.White Blood Cell Differential: Neutrophilia (elevated neutrophils), with decreased eosinophils and lymphocytes.
